detaileddescription.para: Addr responses stored in different caches per (network, local socket) prevent cross-network node identification. If a node for example is multi-homed under Tor and IPv6, a single cache (or no cache at all) would let an attacker to easily detect that it is the same node by comparing responses. Indexing by local socket prevents leakage when a node has multiple listening addresses on the same network.

The used memory equals to 1000 CAddress records (or around 40 bytes) per distinct Network (up to 5) we have/had an inbound peer from, resulting in at most ~196 KB. Every separate local socket may add up to ~196 KB extra.
Services this node offers.
This data is replicated in each Peer instance we create.
This data is not marked const, but after being set it should not change. Unless AssumeUTXO is started, in which case, the peer will be limited until the background chain sync finishes.

Maximum number of automatic connections permitted, excluding manual connections but including inbounds. May be changed by the user and is potentially limited by the operating system (number of file descriptors).
Pointer to this node's banman. May be nullptr - check existence before dereferencing.
Addresses that were saved during the previous clean shutdown. We'll attempt to make block-relay-only connections to them.
SipHasher seeds for deterministic randomness
This is signaled when network activity should cease. A copy of this is saved in m_i2p_sam_session.
I2P SAM session. Used to accept incoming and make outgoing I2P connections from a persistent address.
flag for deciding to connect to an extra outbound peer, in excess of m_max_outbound_full_relay This takes the place of a feeler connection
flag for initiating extra block-relay-only peer connections. this should only be enabled after initial chain sync has occurred, as these connections are intended to be short-lived and low-bandwidth.
A vector of -bind=<address>:<port>=onion arguments each of which is an address and port that are designated for incoming Tor connections.
flag for adding 'forcerelay' permission to whitelisted inbound and manual peers with default permissions.
flag for adding 'relay' permission to whitelisted inbound and manual peers with default permissions.
flag for whether messages are captured
Mutex protecting m_i2p_sam_sessions.
Mutex protecting m_reconnections.
Cap on the size of m_unused_i2p_sessions, to ensure it does not unexpectedly use too much memory.

detaileddescription.para:
Open a new P2P connection and initialize it with the PeerManager at m_msgproc.
addrConnect
Address to connect to, if pszDest is nullptr.
fCountFailure
Increment the number of connection attempts to this address in Addrman.
grant_outbound
Take ownership of this grant, to be released later when the connection is closed.
pszDest
Address to resolve and connect to.
conn_type
Type of the connection to open, must not be ConnectionType::INBOUND.
use_v2transport
Use P2P encryption, (aka V2 transport, BIP324).
proxy_override
Optional proxy to use and override normal proxy selection.
true
The connection was opened successfully.
false
The connection attempt failed.

memberdef.argsstring: (size_t max_addresses, size_t max_pct, std::optional< Network > network, const bool filtered=true) const
memberdef.name: GetAddressesUnsafe

detaileddescription.para: Return randomly selected addresses. This function does not use the address response cache and should only be used in trusted contexts.
An untrusted caller (e.g. from p2p) should instead use GetAddresses to use the cache.

parameterdescription.para: Maximum number of addresses to return (0 = all).
Maximum percentage of addresses to return (0 = all). Value must be from 0 to 100.
Select only addresses of this network (nullopt = all).
Select only addresses that are considered high quality (false = all).

detaileddescription.para: Return addresses from the per-requestor cache. If no cache entry exists, it is populated with randomly selected addresses. This function can be used in untrusted contexts.
A trusted caller (e.g. from RPC or a peer with addr permission) can use GetAddressesUnsafe to avoid using the cache.

parameterdescription.para: The requesting peer. Used to key the cache to prevent privacy leaks.
Maximum number of addresses to return (0 = all). Ignored when cache already contains an entry for requestor.
Maximum percentage of addresses to return (0 = all). Value must be from 0 to 100. Ignored when cache already contains an entry for requestor.

detaileddescription.para: Attempts to open a connection. Currently only used from tests.

parameterdescription.para: Address of node to try connecting to
Set to true if node attempts to connect using BIP 324 v2 transport protocol.

simplesect.para:
bool Returns false if there are no available slots for this connection:
conn_type not a supported ConnectionType
Max total outbound connection capacity filled
Max connection capacity for type is filled

detaileddescription.para: Used to convey which local services we are offering peers during node connection.
The data returned by this is used in CNode construction, which is used to advertise which services we are offering that peer during net_processing.cpp:PushNodeVersion().
Updates the local services that this node advertises to other peers during connection handshake.
check if the outbound target is reached if param historicalBlockServingLimit is set true, the function will response true if the limit for serving historical blocks has been reached
response the bytes left in the current max outbound cycle in case of no limit, it will always response 0
Get a unique deterministic randomizer.
Return true if we should disconnect the peer for failing an inactivity check.
returns the time left in the current max outbound cycle in case of no limit, it will always return 0

Determine whether we're already connected to a given "host:port". Note that for inbound connections, the peer is likely using a random outbound port on their side, so this will likely not match any inbound connections.
host
String of the form "host[:port]", e.g. "localhost" or "localhost:8333" or "1.2.3.4:8333".
true if connected to host.

Determine whether we're already connected to a given address:port. Note that for inbound connections, the peer is likely using a random outbound port on their side, so this will likely not match any inbound connections.
addr_port
Address and port to check.
true if connected to addr_port.
Determine whether we're already connected to a given address.

Try to find a connection to evict when the node is full. Extreme care must be taken to avoid opening the node to attacker triggered network partitioning. The strategy used here is to protect a small number of peers for each of several distinct characteristics which are difficult to forge. In order to partition a node the attacker must be simultaneously better at all of them than honest peers.

detaileddescription.para: Return reachable networks for which we have no addresses in addrman and therefore may require loading fixed seeds.
Return vector of current BLOCK_RELAY peers.

Search for a "preferred" network, a reachable network to which we currently don't have any OUTBOUND_FULL_RELAY or MANUAL connections. There needs to be at least one address in AddrMan for a preferred network to be picked.

simplesect.para: bool Whether a preferred network was found.

memberdef.definition: std::array< unsigned int, Network::NET_MAX > m_network_conn_counts GUARDED_BY
memberdef.name: GUARDED_BY

detaileddescription.para: flag for waking the message processor.

A pool of created I2P SAM transient sessions that should be used instead of creating new ones in order to reduce the load on the I2P network. Creating a session in I2P is not cheap, thus if this is not empty, then pick an entry from it instead of creating a new session. If connecting to a host fails, then the created session is put to this pool for reuse.
List of reconnections we have to make.
Attempt reconnections, if m_reconnections non-empty.
